docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Services Services Documentation

Configure providers, credentials, balances, and fee profiles that power your payment flows.

Start with Overview Browse Services list This documentation describes the Admin UI behavior. Any API examples are illustrative and contain no sensitive data.

docs.title: What this documentation covers
docs.text:
A Service is a configuration unit that connects a payment Provider with the required Credentials and operational settings. In this section you will learn how to create, validate, and maintain services in a safe and predictable way.

Security and compliance Do not place real card data (PAN, CVV), full bank account numbers, or production secrets in screenshots, examples, or logs. Use masked values and placeholders.

docs.title: Explore
docs.text: Overview A short introduction to Services, key entities, and how pages are organized. Services list Find existing services, review status, and open Service details. Create and edit a service Create a new service, choose provider, connect credentials, and set defaults. Service details page Understand the details page, states, validation messages, and actions. Credentials by provider Create and manage provider credentials and reuse them across services. Balances Track, update, and troubleshoot operational balances per currency. Fee profiles Define fee rules and assign them to services and currencies. Troubleshooting Common issues, quick checks, and what to collect before contacting support.

docs.title: Recommended reading order
docs.text:
1. Overview
  2. Services list
  3. Create and edit a service
  4. Service details page
  5. Credentials by provider
  6. Balances and Fee profiles
  7. Troubleshooting

docs.title: Diagrams and screenshots
docs.text:
Use diagrams and UI screenshots to clarify complex behavior.

Recommended locations:

  • docs/assets/images/diagrams/ — conceptual diagrams
  • docs/assets/images/screens/ — UI screenshots

docs.title: Example embed
docs.text: ```html

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Balances section describes how funds are tracked and managed for a service. A balance represents the available amount for a specific currency and is used to support financial operations such as payments and payouts.

Each service can have one or more balances, depending on the currencies it supports.

docs.title: Where to find
docs.text:
Navigation Services → Services list → Row actions → Balances Service details page → Balances

Both navigation paths open the balances view for the selected service.

docs.title: Balances view
docs.text:
Balances are displayed as a set of cards grouped by currency.

Each card represents the current balance amount for a specific currency.

From this view, users can:

  • review available balances
  • add a new balance for a currency
  • update an existing balance
  • remove a balance if it is no longer required
  • refresh balance values using synchronization

docs.title: Balance information
docs.text:
Each balance includes the following information:

Field Description Currency Currency code associated with the balance. Balance Current available amount.

Balances are always linked to a specific service and currency.

docs.title: Create a balance
docs.text:
A new balance can be added for a service if a required currency is not yet configured.

To create a balance:

  1. Select New balance.
  2. Choose a currency.
  3. Save the configuration.

After creation, the balance appears as a new card in the balances view.

docs.title: Update a balance
docs.text:
Existing balances can be updated to reflect the current available amount.

To update a balance:

  1. Select Edit on the balance card.
  2. Update the balance value.
  3. Save the changes.

The updated amount is applied immediately after saving.

docs.title: Delete a balance
docs.text:
Balances can be removed if they are no longer required for the service.

To delete a balance:

  1. Select Delete on the balance card.
  2. Confirm the action.

Once deleted, the balance is removed from the service configuration.

docs.title: Update balances action
docs.text:
The Update balances action refreshes balance values for the service.

This action is typically used to:

  • synchronize balances with the provider
  • ensure balance values reflect the latest available data

The exact behavior of balance synchronization depends on provider capabilities and configuration.

docs.title: Get balances for a service
docs.text:
GET /api/v1/services/{serviceId}/balances
Authorization: Bearer <access_token>

docs.title: Example response
docs.text:
{
  "serviceId": "srv_10293",
  "balances": [
    {
      "currency": "EUR",
      "amount": 12500.75
    },
    {
      "currency": "USD",
      "amount": 8400.00
    }
  ]
}

No sensitive payment data is included in balance responses.

docs.title: Configuration model example
docs.text:
{
  "serviceId": "srv_10293",
  "currency": "EUR",
  "amount": 12500.75
}

Values shown are illustrative and do not represent real account data.

docs.title: Notes and considerations
docs.text:
• Each balance is associated with a single currency.
  • A balance must exist for a currency before it can be updated.
  • Balance availability and synchronization behavior may vary by provider.
  • Changes to balances may affect service operations.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
After configuring balances:

  • review service configuration on the Service details page
  • configure transaction fees in the Fee profiles section

docs.title: Create and edit a service
docs.text:
This page describes how to create a new service and edit an existing one. A service represents a configured integration between the platform and a selected provider and defines how transactions are processed.

Service configuration includes general settings, provider selection, and provider-specific credentials.

docs.title: Where to find
docs.text: Navigation Services → New service Services → Services list → Row actions → Edit

docs.title: Create a service
docs.text: To create a new service, open the Create service form from the Services list.

docs.title: Basic information
docs.text:
When creating a service, the following basic fields are required:

Field Description Name Service name used for identification. Provider Selected service provider. Type Service type (for example, external or internal). Testing Indicates whether the service is used in a test environment.

After selecting a provider, additional provider-specific fields may become available.

docs.title: Provider credentials
docs.text:
Provider credentials are required to authenticate requests sent to the provider system.

Credential fields are dynamic and depend on the selected provider. Typical credential types include:

  • API keys
  • merchant identifiers
  • access tokens

Credential values are stored securely and are not displayed after saving.

docs.title: Save behavior
docs.text:
If required fields are missing or invalid:

  • the system highlights affected fields
  • the service cannot be saved

After successful creation:

  • the service is saved in Inactive status
  • the service appears in the Services list

docs.title: Edit a service
docs.text:
Existing services can be modified using the Edit action.

The Update service form allows you to:

  • update general service settings
  • modify provider credentials
  • enable or disable testing mode

Some fields may be restricted depending on provider or service state.

docs.title: Service status
docs.text:
A service can be switched between statuses:

  • Inactive - the service is configured but not used
  • Active - the service is available for operations

A service can only be activated if:

  • all required fields are completed
  • provider credentials are valid

docs.title: Credential handling and security
docs.text:
Credential values:

  • are stored in a secure storage
  • are not exposed in logs or responses
  • are not returned by the API after creation

Only the presence of credentials is visible in the user interface.

docs.title: Configuration model example
docs.text:
The following example illustrates a simplified service configuration model. Values shown are placeholders and do not represent real credentials. 

{
  "serviceId": "srv_10293",
  "name": "Main Provider Service",
  "provider": "THEDEX",
  "type": "EXTERNAL",
  "testing": false,
  "status": "INACTIVE",
  "credentialsRef": "secret://providers/thedex/prod"
}

docs.title: API example
docs.text: Services can also be managed programmatically via API.

docs.title: Create a service
docs.text:
POST /api/v1/services
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
{
  "name": "Main Provider Service",
  "provider": "THEDEX",
  "type": "EXTERNAL",
  "testing": false
}

docs.title: Successful response
docs.text:
{
  "serviceId": "srv_10293",
  "status": "INACTIVE",
  "createdAt": "2024-06-01T12:44:18Z"
}

Sensitive credential values are never returned in API responses.

docs.title: Notes and considerations
docs.text:
• Credential requirements vary by provider.
  • Services must be active before they can be used for transactions.
  • Changes to provider credentials may temporarily affect service availability.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
After creating or updating a service:

  • review configuration on the Service details page
  • configure provider credentials in Credentials by provider
  • set up financial rules in Balances and Fee profiles

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Each payment provider requires a specific set of credentials for authentication and communication. The required credential fields depend on the selected provider and are validated by the system during service configuration.

This page provides an overview of credential requirements for supported providers.

docs.title: How credentials work
docs.text:
When a provider is selected during service creation or editing, the system dynamically displays the credential fields required for that provider.

All required credential fields must be completed before a service can be saved or activated.

docs.title: Provider credential requirements
docs.text:
The table below lists credential fields required for each provider.

Provider Credential field Description Required Paylogic POINT Provider access point identifier. Yes Paylogic SERVICE Provider service identifier. Yes Paylogic PUBLIC-KEY Public key used for authentication. Yes Paylogic PRIVATE-KEY Private key used for authentication. Yes Bill Line MERCHANT Merchant identifier. Yes Bill Line SECRET-KEY Secret key for API authentication. Yes Thedex API-KEY API key issued by the provider. Yes Thedex SECRET-KEY Secret key used for request signing. Yes Thedex MERCHANT-ID Merchant identifier assigned by the provider. Yes

Credential names and formats are defined by the provider.

docs.title: Validation rules
docs.text:
The system validates provider credentials before saving a service.

Validation behavior includes:

  • required fields cannot be empty
  • credential values must match provider-defined formats
  • missing or invalid credentials prevent service activation

If validation fails, the system highlights the affected field and displays a corresponding error message.

docs.title: Credential updates
docs.text:
Provider credentials can be updated through the service edit workflow.

When credentials are updated:

  • changes are applied immediately after validation
  • provider connectivity may be affected
  • related operations may be temporarily unavailable

docs.title: Security considerations
docs.text:
• Credential values are handled as sensitive information.
  • Access to credential configuration should be restricted to authorized users.
  • Credentials should be updated according to provider security requirements.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Credential requirements may change if a provider updates its integration specifications.
  • Additional providers may introduce new credential fields.
  • Always verify credential accuracy before activating a service.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
After configuring provider credentials:

  • review service status on the Service details page
  • configure balances in the Balances section
  • assign fee rules in the Fee profiles section

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Fee profiles section describes how transaction fees are configured for a service. A fee profile defines the rules used to calculate fees for different transaction types processed through the service.

Fee profiles are typically configured per currency and become effective from a defined start date.

docs.title: Where to find
docs.text:
Navigation Service details page → Fee profiles

This navigation path opens the fee profiles view for the selected service.

docs.title: Fee profiles view
docs.text:
Fee profiles are displayed as a table listing all profiles configured for the service.

The table allows users to quickly review fee settings and identify which rules are currently active.

Typical information displayed includes:

  • profile name
  • currency
  • start date
  • configured fee components

docs.title: Fee profile structure
docs.text:
A fee profile consists of one or more fee components, each defining how a specific transaction type is charged.

Common fee components include:

  • deposit fees
  • withdrawal fees
  • refund fees
  • decline fees
  • chargeback fees
  • settlement fees
  • rolling reserve settings

The availability of components depends on provider capabilities and service configuration.

docs.title: Create a fee profile
docs.text:
To create a new fee profile:

  1. Select Create fee profile.
  2. Enter a profile name.
  3. Select the currency.
  4. Set the start date.
  5. Configure required fee components.
  6. Save the configuration.

After creation, the fee profile becomes available for use by the service when the start date is reached.

docs.title: Fee components
docs.text:
Fee components define how fees are calculated for a given transaction type.

Each component may include the following parameters:

Parameter Description Fee % Percentage-based fee applied to the transaction amount. Fee fix Fixed fee amount. Min fee Minimum fee value. Max fee Maximum fee value.

Not all parameters are required for every component.

docs.title: Rolling reserve
docs.text:
Rolling reserve defines a portion of funds that is temporarily withheld to mitigate financial risk.

Typical rolling reserve configuration includes:

  • reserve percentage
  • holding period

Rolling reserve behavior and availability depend on provider support.

docs.title: Settlement
docs.text:
Settlement settings define how and when funds are settled.

Settlement configuration may include:

  • settlement period
  • settlement delay
  • settlement-related fees

Settlement behavior may vary by provider and currency.

docs.title: Configuration model example
docs.text:
The following example illustrates a simplified fee profile configuration.

Values shown are placeholders and do not represent real commercial conditions.

{
  "profileId": "fee_20491",
  "serviceId": "srv_10293",
  "currency": "EUR",
  "startDate": "2024-07-01",
  "components": {
    "deposit": {
      "percentage": 2.5,
      "fixed": 0.30
    },
    "withdrawal": {
      "percentage": 1.8,
      "min": 1.00
    }
  }
}

docs.title: API example (optional reference)
docs.text: Fee profiles can also be managed programmatically.

docs.title: Create a fee profile
docs.text:
POST /api/v1/services/{serviceId}/fee-profiles
Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
Content-Type: application/json
{
  "name": "Standard EUR fees",
  "currency": "EUR",
  "startDate": "2024-07-01"
}

docs.title: Successful response
docs.text:
{
  "profileId": "fee_20491",
  "status": "ACTIVE"
}

Fee calculation details are applied internally and are not exposed in transaction responses.

docs.title: Notes and considerations
docs.text:
• Fee profiles are applied per currency.
  • Only one fee profile can be active for a currency at a given time.
  • Changes to fee profiles may affect transaction costs immediately after activation.
  • Provider limitations may restrict available fee components.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
After configuring fee profiles:

  • review balances in the Balances section
  • verify overall configuration on the Service details page

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
Glossary

This glossary explains the key terms used throughout the Services documentation. Use it to quickly clarify concepts such as services, balances, fee profiles, and provider credentials while reading the guides.

Balance The amount of funds available for a service in a specific currency. Balances are used to support financial operations and may be updated manually or synchronized with a provider.

Credential A provider-specific value required to authenticate and authorize a service. Examples include API keys, secret keys, merchant IDs, or access tokens.

Currency A monetary unit used for transactions and balances. Each balance and fee profile is configured for a specific currency.

Fee component An individual rule within a fee profile that defines how a fee is calculated for a specific transaction type, such as deposits or withdrawals.

Fee profile A set of fee rules applied to transactions processed by a service. Fee profiles are usually configured per currency and may include multiple fee components.

Provider An external system or payment processor that handles transactions on behalf of the platform. Providers define credential requirements and supported capabilities.

Rolling reserve A portion of funds that is temporarily withheld for a defined period. Rolling reserves are commonly used to mitigate financial risk.

Service A configured integration that connects the platform to a specific provider. Services define how transactions are processed, authenticated, and managed.

Service status The current operational state of a service, such as active or inactive. Only active services are typically used for processing transactions.

Settlement The process of transferring funds after transactions are completed. Settlement rules define timing, delays, and applicable fees.

Validation message A system message displayed when configuration rules are not met. Validation messages usually indicate missing, incorrect, or incompatible values.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This section explains how to configure and maintain Services in the platform.

A Service is a configuration unit that links a selected Provider with the required Credentials and defines how the platform operates with that provider.

A service configuration determines:

  • Which credentials are used for authentication
  • Which balances are tracked and in which currencies
  • Which fee profiles are applied for calculations and reporting

In most setups, a single provider can have multiple services (for example, to separate environments, regions, merchants, or credential sets).

docs.title: When to use this section
docs.text:
Use this section if you need to:

  • Review existing services and their configuration
  • Create or update a service
  • Verify credentials, balances, or fee setup
  • Troubleshoot service-related issues

docs.title: How to use this section
docs.text:
A typical workflow looks like this:

  1. Review the existing setup in Services list
  2. Create or update a service (provider, credentials, and operational parameters)
  3. Validate the configuration on the service details page
  4. Make sure balances and fees are configured correctly
  5. Use troubleshooting steps if something does not work as expected

docs.title: Pages in this section
docs.text:
Start here depending on what you want to do:

  • Services list - view all configured services and open a specific service Open Services list

  • Create and edit a service - create a new service or update an existing one Open Create and edit a service

  • Service details page - validate configuration and review service-related entities Open Service details page

  • Credentials by provider - understand how credentials are used and managed for specific providers Open Credentials by provider

docs.title: Related topics
docs.text:
These pages are often used together with Services:

  • Balances - balance tracking per service and currency Open Balances

  • Fee profiles - fee profile configuration and usage Open Fee profiles

  • Troubleshooting - common checks and typical issues in this area Open Troubleshooting

  • Glossary - terminology used in this documentation Open Glossary

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Service details page provides a consolidated view of a single service configuration.   It allows users to review base service information, current status, and navigate to related configurations such   as balances and fee profiles.

docs.title: Where to find
docs.text:
Navigation Services → Services list → Service name

Selecting a service name opens the Service details page.

docs.title: Base information
docs.text: The upper section of the page displays base service information.

docs.title: Base information fields
docs.text:
Field Description Name Service name. Status Current service status (Active or Inactive). Provider Payment service provider. Provider ID Provider-specific identifier. Type Service type (Internal or External). ID Unique service identifier. Created Date and time when the service was created. Updated Date and time of the last update.

These fields provide a read-only overview of the service configuration.

docs.title: Available actions
docs.text:
The Service details page provides quick access to related configurations.

Balances Select Balances to view and manage balances associated with the service. Fee profiles Select Fee profiles to view or configure fee rules applied to transactions processed through the service. Edit service Select Edit to update service configuration, credentials, or status.

docs.title: Service status visibility
docs.text:
The service status displayed on this page reflects the current operational state of the service.

  • Active services can be used in operations.
  • Inactive services are disabled but remain available for review and configuration.

docs.title: Notes and considerations
docs.text:
• The Service details page is read-only except for navigation actions.
  • Changes to service configuration are performed through the edit workflow.
  • Updates to a service may affect related balances and fee profiles.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
From this page, you can:

  • manage balances in the Balances section
  • configure fees in the Fee profiles section
  • update service configuration using Edit

docs.title: Services list
docs.text: Services list    The Services list page displays all configured services and provides access to key service management actions.   From this page, users can review service status, identify provider connections, and navigate to detailed service configuration.

docs.title: Where to find
docs.text: Navigation Left Sidebar → Services

docs.title: Services table
docs.text: The Services list is presented as a table containing all existing services.

docs.title: Table columns
docs.text:
Column Description ID Unique identifier of the service Name Service name Status Current service status (Active or Inactive) SP Service provider name SP ID Provider-specific service identifier Type Service type (Internal or External) Created Date and time when the service was created

The table allows quick comparison of service configurations and operational states.

docs.title: Available actions
docs.text:
Create a new service

To create a new service, select New service. This opens a configuration panel where provider details, credentials, and operational parameters can be defined.

View service details

Selecting a service name opens the Service details page, where base information and related configurations can be reviewed.

docs.title: Row actions
docs.text:
Each service row provides additional actions via the row menu:

  • Balances - opens the balances associated with the selected service
  • Edit - opens the service configuration panel for editing

Available actions depend on the current service configuration and status.

docs.title: Service status behavior
docs.text:
Service status determines whether the service is available for use:

  • Active - the service can be used in operations
  • Inactive - the service is disabled and not used for processing
Inactive services remain visible in the list for reference and configuration purposes.

docs.title: Notes and considerations
docs.text:
• Only properly configured services can be activated.
  • Provider credentials must be valid for the service to function correctly.
  • Changes made to a service may affect related balances and fee profiles.

docs.title: Next steps
docs.text:
• To configure a new provider connection, continue to Create and edit a service.
  • To review existing configuration, open the Service details

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
This page collects the most common issues you may encounter while creating or updating services, configuring balances, and setting up fee profiles. Most problems are related to missing required fields, provider-specific credential requirements, or configuration mismatches (for example, currency or start date).

If you are unsure where to start, begin with the service configuration panel. In practice, the UI validation messages are usually the fastest way to identify what exactly needs to be corrected.

docs.title: Required fields are missing
docs.text:
If you try to create or update a service with missing required fields, the system will block saving and highlight the fields that must be completed. This is especially common for provider credentials.

You may see messages similar to:

  • SECRET-KEY cannot be empty
  • MERCHANT-ID cannot be empty

Complete the missing values, then save the service again. If you are not sure which credentials are required for the provider, check the Credentials by provider page.

docs.title: Credential value looks correct, but validation still fails
docs.text:
Some providers require credentials in a specific format. In such cases, even a seemingly valid value may be rejected by validation rules.

When this happens, re-check the credential format you received from the provider (for example, expected length, allowed characters, or whether the value should include prefixes). After correcting the value, try saving the service again.

docs.title: Service cannot be activated
docs.text:
If a service cannot be switched to Active, the most common reason is incomplete configuration or invalid credentials. In practice, activation problems almost always trace back to missing required fields in the provider credentials section.

Open the service in Edit, review all required fields, and save the configuration first. After the service is saved without validation errors, change its status again.

docs.title: Balance cannot be updated
docs.text:
If you cannot update a balance, first verify that a balance for the required currency actually exists for the service. A balance must be created before it can be edited.

If the balance exists but values still do not match expectations, use the Update Balances action. This action is typically used to refresh balance values and synchronize them with the provider, when supported.

Keep in mind that balance behavior may vary depending on provider capabilities.

docs.title: Balance is not displayed
docs.text:
If a balance is not visible in the balances view, it is usually caused by one of the following:

  • the balance was deleted
  • you are looking at a different service than intended
  • the service is inactive (depending on how the environment is configured)

Double-check the selected service and verify that the balance exists for the correct currency.

docs.title: Fee profile does not apply as expected
docs.text:
If fees do not apply as expected, start by checking two common configuration mismatches: start date and currency.

If the fee profile start date is in the future, it may not be used yet. Also ensure that the fee profile currency matches the currency used in the service configuration and operations.

docs.title: Practical tips
docs.text:
When troubleshooting configuration issues, these simple steps usually help:

  • Read the validation message first. It often points directly to the incorrect or missing field.
  • Save changes before navigating away from the page to avoid losing edits.
  • If the issue is provider-specific, verify credential requirements and formats for that provider.
  • Treat service activation as a final check: if a service cannot be activated, something in configuration still needs attention.

docs.title: When to escalate
docs.text:
If you cannot resolve the issue with the checks above, prepare a short set of details before escalating:

  • service ID and provider name
  • current status (Active/Inactive)
  • what you were trying to do (create, edit, update balance, create fee profile)
  • the validation message or visible UI behavior

This makes it much easier for the support or technical team to reproduce the issue and respond quickly.
